State Prosecutor Marilyn Mosby unveiled revised charges on Thursday, with the most severe counts - including second-degree murder - remaining in place. Freddie Gray's death in April, following a severe spinal cord injury sustained during police custody, had sparked widespread protests, riots, and looting in Baltimore. According to Mosby, charges can be revised during ongoing investigations as new evidence emerges, which is precisely what occurred in this case. While the grand jury failed to return charges related to false imprisonment, brought against some officers for allegedly unjustified and illegal arrest, it did return new reckless endangerment charges that were not part of the original indictment. Mosby has maintained that Gray's neck was broken during his arrest, specifically while being handcuffed and placed into a police van. Moreover, she claimed that police repeatedly ignored his pleas for assistance.

Baboucarr Ceesay, a 21-year-old from Gambia, is suspected to have perished when the fishing boat he boarded in Libya capsized in the Mediterranean on Sunday. His aunt, Jessica Sey from Cheltenham, lamented that her nephew's family will never receive the justice they deserve and emphasized the need for increased education among migrants about the perilous risks they face. "We're consumed by anger," she expressed. "Those who profit from migrants' money by placing them on these doomed boats must be held accountable. This is no longer a distant issue, but a pressing concern on our doorstep." According to Mrs. Sey, her nephew's decision to migrate to the UK from his home country was a "desperate attempt to escape his circumstances." His illegal journey ultimately proved fatal. As a "promising" young football player who was relatively well-off in his native Gambia, Mr. Sey's desire for a better life in Europe was a driving force behind his decision. He embarked on the perilous journey from Gambia's capital, Banjul, to Guinea, accompanied by a friend, before crossing the Sahara Desert.

For the second consecutive year, a machine learning algorithm has outperformed BBC football commentator Mark Lawrenson's predictions. In response, the team behind the algorithm is now inviting fantasy football enthusiasts to take on the challenge. The researchers believe that the algorithm can also assist players in forming stronger teams. Fantasy football, a game that originated in the UK in 1971, has evolved from a niche recreational activity to a thriving online business. Today, fans play ad-supported versions of the game, download the app, and even wager on match outcomes. There are two primary types of fantasy football games: users can compete against Squadguru's AI in the Challenge the Squadguru league within the free Fantasy Premier League salary cap game by joining a league.

According to a recent report, a large crowd had gathered at the camp, awaiting food aid when the blast occurred. The Jalozai refugee camp is home to individuals fleeing conflict in the tribal regions adjacent to Afghanistan, where numerous Taliban- and al-Qaeda-affiliated militants are believed to be hiding. Notably, police claim that the camp also serves as a hideout for some militants. As of now, no group has claimed responsibility for the attack. It is noteworthy that assaults on refugee camps in Pakistan are extremely rare, although there have been longstanding concerns that militants might attempt to infiltrate Jalozai and other camps. The BBC's M Ilyas Khan, reporting from Islamabad, highlights that just last week, individuals linked to the militant group Lashkar-e-Islam were apprehended by a government-backed tribal force. Police suspect that Thursday's bombing may be a response to this action. The attack was captured live on television, with ambulances rushing victims to the hospital. The blast has left a crater, and authorities are currently investigating the wreckage to gather more information.

According to a city council report, the 2015 yacht racing event in July had a significant impact on visitor numbers and the city's reputation. However, the report also noted that spectators experienced difficulties with ticketing and expressed disappointment with the steel fencing at the event site. In light of these issues, changes are being implemented for this year's event, including the discontinuation of evening entertainment options. The four-day weekend event in July 2015, organized by TeamOrigin Events, served as the opening stage of the sailing series, marking the start of Sir Ben Ainslie Racing's (BAR) bid to win the 35th America's Cup. While the Saturday events drew around 100,000 spectators, inclement weather led to the cancellation of racing and the evacuation of public viewing areas on Sunday. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were among those who were disappointed by the event's abandonment, and there was widespread criticism on social media regarding spectator amenities.

To disperse Shia Muslim protesters demanding action against corruption and security failures, authorities deployed tear gas and live ammunition. A curfew was initially implemented in Baghdad, but has since been lifted. This marks the second time this month that protesters have breached the city's government sector. Shia cleric Moqtada Sadr condemned the use of force, instead endorsing the demonstrators' "peaceful" and "spontaneous" uprising. At least 50 protesters have been injured. The protesters are frustrated with the government's lack of progress on much-needed reforms, amidst its ongoing fight against the Islamic State group (IS) and declining oil revenues. IS, a Sunni jihadist group, has been responsible for a recent surge in attacks in western and northern Iraq, resulting in dozens of casualties. Some protesters managed to enter the prime minister's office and parliament buildings, which are located in the secure Green Zone.

Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister, Peter O'Neill, announced that he had held a meeting with Australia's Immigration Minister, Peter Dutton, in Port Moresby on Wednesday. According to a statement released by O'Neill, both PNG and Australia have reached a consensus that the Manus Island detention center will be shut down. This decision comes after Papua New Guinea's Supreme Court ruled in April that detaining asylum seekers and refugees at the center was unconstitutional. Although the center currently houses 854 men, O'Neill emphasized that the closure will not occur immediately. Instead, a series of options are being explored and implemented, with a focus on careful planning to ensure the interests of Papua New Guinea's citizens and the well-being of asylum seekers and refugees are considered.

The BBC will broadcast the Gfinity Elite Series competition every weekend on BBC Three's online platform. A total of 160 gamers will compete for a £225,000 prize in front of live audiences. The move is expected to draw in new viewers to the e-sports genre, according to an analyst. The partnership includes exclusive editorial content from the Gfinity tournament in west London, which will feature a range of games, including Street Fighter V, Counter Strike: Global Offensive, and Rocket League. Currently, online platforms such as Twitch and YouTube dominate e-sports viewership, but events are also being shown on conventional TV channels like Ginx in the UK. This marks a significant expansion in the BBC's e-sports coverage, which has previously focused on highlighting tournament highlights. According to Piers Harding-Rolls, an analyst at IHS, the Gfinity coverage will be "on a much larger scale" than previous efforts.

The innovative display can mimic the phone's touchscreen, a full-size computer keyboard, or even piano keys. Additionally, the laser projector can project images and videos onto walls with remarkable precision. Lenovo showcased the Smart Cast phone at its recent Tech World conference in Beijing, where it also introduced a new smartwatch design. Notably, the compact laser projector measures just 34mm by 26mm by 5mm and boasts the ability to produce sharp images without requiring focusing. A demonstration video highlights the device's versatility, revealing how adjusting the mounting for the lens transforms it from a standard projector to a "surface mode" that beams the display onto any flat surface.

A recent poll conducted by the Met Police Federation aimed to assess officers' opinions on firearms in the context of ongoing terrorist threats. Out of the 11,000 officers who participated, a mere 6% felt that there were sufficient numbers of officers carrying guns. In response, the Met has announced plans to increase the number of firearm officers by 600. The UK's threat level for international terrorism has been classified as severe since August 2014, indicating a high likelihood of an attack. The poll revealed that 43% of officers believed there should be more specialist firearm officers, while 26% advocated for routine arming of all officers. Conversely, 12% expressed reluctance to carry firearms under any circumstances. Interestingly, 6.7% of the total police force, or 2,139 authorized firearms officers, are responsible for executing 3,974 police firearms operations between March 2015 and March 2016. Moreover, police firearms were discharged in 7 incidents during the 2015-2016 period. The poll also found strong support for Tasers, with 75% of officers believing all officers should be equipped with one.

As Team Sky's key rider, 28-year-old Thomas is committed to helping Chris Froome secure his second consecutive Tour de France title. However, Froome's chances were dealt a blow when he crashed during the fourth stage, prompting an X-ray to assess the severity of his injuries. Thomas expressed concerns about the potentially hazardous cobbled road conditions, warning that rain could have disastrous consequences for any rider involved. "You train all year for this moment, and to have it end abruptly due to bad luck would be heartbreaking," he said, hoping that the weather stays dry and the riders avoid trouble. Froome's mishap occurred just five kilometers into the 163.5km stage, where he suffered a grazed left hip and wrist injury before receiving medical attention and rejoining the peloton. Despite the setback, Froome currently holds seventh place overall, just two seconds behind Vincenzo Nibali, the stage four winner Marcel Kittel, and the rest of the pack. The drama unfolded on Wednesday, with the next stage yet to come.

The Virginia public school district is facing a court challenge regarding its attempt to prohibit a 17-year-old transgender student, who was born female but identifies as male, from using the boys' bathroom. The Supreme Court is anticipated to render a decision on this case by the end of June. With one vacancy on the bench following the passing of Antonin Scalia, the justices may potentially issue a 4-4 tie, which could have significant implications for the case. Nationwide, school districts remain divided on the issue of whether transgender students should be required to use bathrooms corresponding with the sex listed on their birth certificates. The Supreme Court has accepted a petition from Gloucester County, Virginia, ruling in favor of the school board, which had appealed a lower court's decision ordering the district to allow Gavin Grimm, a transgender student, to use the boys' bathroom. Gavin, a high school freshman, publicly identified as a transgender boy during his first year of high school and subsequently filed a lawsuit against the school board.

According to Angus Campbell, leader of Comhairle nan Eilean Siar, the airline operating the route offers more affordable fares to reach the Algarve than Stornoway. The Facebook campaign, which has garnered over 11,000 likes, has sparked debate. Loganair, which operates the island routes on behalf of Flybe, has defended its pricing structure, citing discounts for children, students, hospital visitors, and islanders. Campbell emphasized that reducing airfare costs is a key priority for Our Islands Our Future, a project seeking increased autonomy for Shetland, Orkney, and Western Isles councils. He noted: "Many islanders have raised concerns about high fares. For instance, I recently checked the Flybe website and found that a round-trip flight from Stornoway to Glasgow, departing on Wednesday and returning on Thursday, costs a total of £351. Only a few days later, the same airline offers similar fares to the Algarve."

Cleveland Police have been accused of attempting to monitor the activities of six individuals following a 2012 front-page article in the Northern Echo. According to the Echo, this group included reporters, a staff member, and a solicitor. Despite the allegations, the police force has refused to comment to the BBC. A complaint has been filed with the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) by the Police Federation. The police allegedly utilized the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIPA) to identify the whistleblower, which permits surveillance in cases involving crime or public safety concerns. The application was reportedly made after the Echo published a story based on an internal police report detailing institutionalized racism within the force. When questioned by the Echo, a Cleveland Police spokesperson declined to confirm or deny whether a RIPA application was made to monitor the phone activity of three journalists, a serving police officer, a solicitor, and the then-chairman of the Cleveland Police Federation.

A study conducted by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) discovered that nearly a quarter of new fathers did not take any paternity leave, while only about 9% took more than the standard two weeks of statutory leave. The research attributed this phenomenon to "deeply ingrained" attitudes among employers and new fathers' concerns about financial constraints. The findings highlighted the need to address these attitudes, as the government's upcoming plan to allow parents to share maternity and paternity leave in April 2015 may have limited impact without a cultural shift. According to Charles Elvin, ILM chief executive, the introduction of shared parental leave is a crucial step towards enabling more women to advance to senior roles, yet the study revealed that cultural barriers are hindering the uptake of both statutory and additional paternity leave. The research suggests that there is a lingering cultural expectation within organizations that women, rather than men, should be the primary caregivers, which must be overcome to promote greater work-life balance and equality.

On March 14, a tragic accident occurred when the Irish Coastguard Rescue Helicopter 116 crashed, resulting in the loss of four lives on board. Despite being rescued from the sea, Captain Dara Fitzpatrick sadly succumbed to her injuries. The search for the remaining three crew members is ongoing, with divers being delayed until Friday due to unfavorable weather conditions. However, on Friday, the divers were able to make significant progress, with Supt Tony Healy of the Garda (Irish Police) reporting that they were actively working on the seabed. Although they will not continue their search once night falls, their primary objective remains the recovery of the crew. In a separate development, Jurgen Whyte, chief inspector with the IAAIU, announced a major breakthrough, revealing that the data recorder was successfully recovered from the seabed off Blackrock at 4:30 pm. The recorder will be transported to Dublin before being sent to the UK air accident investigation branch for further analysis and preparation.

Since its October opening, over 130,000 visitors have attended the exhibition, which features an impressive lineup of works, including Vermeer's smallest known piece, The Lacemaker. This rare loan from The Louvre, showcased in the UK for the first time, is a major draw. To accommodate the high demand, the museum is extending its opening hours for the exhibition's final two weeks. The exhibition's popularity is largely attributed to The Lacemaker's inclusion, according to curator Betsy Wiseman. She notes, "The Louvre only lends this painting sparingly, as it holds significant value in their collection, comparable to the Mona Lisa." Additionally, the exhibition boasts A Lady At The Virginals With A Gentleman (The Music Lesson), on loan from The Royal Collection, and A Young Woman Seated At A Virginal, from the National Gallery, London.

The body of 51-year-old Helen Bailey was discovered in a cess pit at her residence in Royston, Hertfordshire, in July 2016, nearly three months after she went missing on April 11. Ian Stewart, her fiancé, has denied the charge of murder. A crucial piece of testimony came from Edward Farmer, who initially claimed to have seen Bailey in a car in Broadstairs, Kent, between mid-April and June. However, under further questioning, he conceded that the sighting could have taken place weeks earlier. According to Farmer, he saw Bailey driving a dark-colored Range Rover or 4x4 on Charlotte Street, near her holiday home in Broadstairs, seemingly unaccompanied. This account contradicts defense claims that Bailey was kidnapped by two violent men who allegedly took her to Broadstairs. When pressed about the date of the alleged sighting, Farmer estimated it was around five to six weeks prior to his police interview.

The minutes from the Federal Reserve's October meeting reveal that policymakers were concerned about the impact of stock market volatility and global economic weakness on the US economy. Notwithstanding these concerns, they were careful not to send a negative signal, instead emphasizing their confidence in the country's economic fundamentals. As a result, they decided to bring an end to their quantitative easing (QE) program, which involved purchasing bonds to keep long-term interest rates low and stimulate spending. According to the minutes, Fed officials were united in their view that the economy's underlying strength was sufficient to support continued progress towards maximum employment. The news was met with a muted reaction from US markets, with the Dow Jones initially rising before falling back into the red. To alleviate concerns and reiterate their commitment to their policy path, the Fed sought to reassure investors that they would not deviate from their planned course.

Robin Waistell claimed that he was unable to sell his property in Maesteg due to the lack of action from Network Rail to eradicate the invasive Japanese knotweed on the railway embankment behind his home. This case is seen as a potential precedent for homeowners whose properties are affected by knotweed on railway land. Network Rail has announced that it will thoroughly review the judgement. It appears that the rail infrastructure body was denied immediate leave to appeal against the ruling. As a result, Network Rail may face legal costs in the range of six figures following its loss in the Cardiff court case brought by Mr. Waistell and his neighbor. The 70-year-old Mr. Waistell, a widower who relocated to the bungalow from Spain after the death of his wife, had hoped to return to the sun but was unable to due to the knotweed issue, which was hindering the sale of his property.

At his confirmation hearing, Rex Tillerson sparked controversy by likening China's artificial island construction to Russia's annexation of Crimea. This bold comparison was made in reference to Beijing's extensive building efforts on reefs in waters disputed by other nations. As revealed by recent images, some of these artificial islands are now equipped with military defenses, according to a think-tank. Tillerson emphasized the need to send a clear message to China, stating that the island-building must cease and that the country's access to these islands will not be permitted. The regional community has expressed deep concern over China's actions, as Beijing claims sovereignty over nearly the entire South China Sea. However, Vietnam, the Philippines, Taiwan, Malaysia, and Brunei also have competing claims to the area. In July, an international tribunal ruled against China's claims, supporting the Philippines' case, but Beijing refused to acknowledge the verdict.

The council has announced that it may soon introduce index-linked bonds, pending market conditions. Notably, Aberdeen became the first local authority in Scotland to receive a credit rating from Moody's Investors Service, securing an Aa2 issuer credit rating. The funding will support a £1 billion capital programme. Council leader Jennifer Laing expressed enthusiasm, stating that the prospect of issuing bonds could be a groundbreaking moment in the city's history. This would be a first for a Scottish local authority, marking a significant innovation in public sector finance. Laing emphasized that the council's proactive approach to capital funding is driven by a commitment to preserving the revenue budget, which underpins service delivery.

Media playback may not be supported on this device, but Stanford and Holland still managed to shine behind world champion Gwen Jorgensen in Chicago. Jorgensen, an American athlete, pulled away on the run to claim her second consecutive world title, extending her winning streak to 15. "I've been heavily focused on meeting the criteria, and it's been an understatement to say I haven't been sweating over it," said Stanford, a former world champion from Wales, who is also the second Welsh woman to secure her Rio spot alongside sailor Hannah Mills. Holland, who finished on the podium, expressed satisfaction with her performance, noting that staying with the leaders during the final leg of the competition was her primary goal. Jorgensen completed the course, which consisted of a 1.5km swim, 40km cycle, and 10km run, in one hour 55 minutes and 36 seconds. Stanford finished 29 seconds behind Jorgensen.

The General Municipal, Boilermakers and Allied Trade Union (GMB) Scotland has warned that the terms and conditions of its offshore industry members are under threat. The union is seeking permission from its regional committee to hold a ballot among members covered by the Offshore Contractors Agreement to determine whether they are willing to take strike action. This move follows a similar announcement by Unite over the weekend. The situation arises as several oil and gas companies operating in the North Sea have announced plans to reduce staff and cut salaries in response to a prolonged decline in oil prices. The GMB's decision to consider strike action comes after failed negotiations between the union and the Offshore Contractors Association (OCA) on Friday. The Offshore Contractors Agreement covers a range of sectors, including mechanical, electrical, and allied services, construction, maintenance, design, project engineering, fabrication, and decommissioning. According to GMB Scotland regional officer John Kelly, "some oil companies and contractors are displaying blatant opportunism by seeking to fundamentally alter the terms and conditions of our members."

The Saddlers seemed poised to take the lead in the first half, but Albion goalkeeper Jon McLaughlin thwarted their efforts by denying Paul Downing and Romaine Sawyers. Meanwhile, Burton's Stuart Beavon managed to trick his way into Walsall's box, only to fire the ball into the side-netting. Wigan's victory over Bury has narrowed the gap between Albion and Walsall, with the latter maintaining their fourth-place standing. Speaking to BBC Radio Derby, Burton Albion manager Nigel Clough reflected, "It was a closely contested match, with neither team creating many scoring opportunities. We're pleased to have earned another point and secured a clean sheet." He added, "While we didn't quite match our performance from Monday night in terms of possession, we've reverted to our strong suit - being solid and defensive-minded - which has served us well over the past year or two." Walsall head coach Sean O'Driscoll also shared his thoughts, although the specific quote is not provided in the original text.

During his three-day official visit to the United States, the prime minister engaged in two-hour talks with US President Barack Obama at the White House, where he broached the topic of extradition rules. Critics of the existing regulations argue that they facilitate the extradition of UK nationals by allowing US authorities to present less evidence in support of their claims. However, a senior judge's 2011 review concluded that the rules were fair to British citizens. According to the BBC's political editor, Nick Robinson, the prime minister's discussion with Obama focused on the practical implementation of extradition rules. Concerns surrounding the 2003 US-UK extradition treaty have been raised in recent years, particularly in cases involving British citizens such as Christopher Tappin and Gary McKinnon. Parliament's Joint Committee on Human Rights has urged the government to renegotiate the treaty, citing its perceived imbalance.

In the fictional game Fiscal Kombat, players take on the role of Jean-Luc Mélenchon as they navigate the streets, engaging in a battle against wealthy oligarchs and rival politicians. The objective is to extract funds from the affluent to finance Mélenchon's policy initiatives. The player's primary challenge is to accumulate as much wealth as possible while evading the attempts of the wealthy to inflict harm or even death. Among the game's "bosses" are notable figures such as former French President Nicolas Sarkozy, International Monetary Fund (IMF) head Christine Lagarde, tax-evading politician Jérôme Cahuzac, and L'Oréal heiress Liliane Bettencourt. Additionally, players must defeat presidential rivals Emmanuel Macron and François Fillon. According to Le Monde, the game was created by Mélenchon supporters who met on the Jeuxvideo.com gaming forum's 18-25 chatroom. The game has since gained widespread acceptance, with the candidate himself embracing the game.

The proposed merger between Bouygues Telecom and SFR, owned by Vivendi, would form the largest mobile phone service provider in France, leaving only three major players in the market. Altice, another prominent firm, has also submitted a bid for SFR, but the amount of its offer remains undisclosed. As France's second and third largest mobile phone companies, Bouygues Telecom and SFR would, through this merger, surpass Orange to become the leading mobile phone company in France. The deal, however, requires approval from French and European Union competition regulators, a process that has already raised concerns in Brussels following a similar offer by Telefonica for E-Plus in Germany. Industry experts point out that the Bouygues offer is part of a broader trend of consolidation among mobile phone companies.

Doreen Collyer, a 60-year-old former lecturer at the University of Chester, was tragically killed while scuba diving in Perth on Sunday. According to reports, a 16ft great white shark was responsible for her death. Her husband, David Collyer, described her as a "beautiful person" and a "loving wife". The couple had relocated to Australia from Cheshire, UK, around five years ago. As a certified diver with an advanced open water qualification, Mrs Collyer was well-equipped for her underwater adventures. Unfortunately, her diving partner managed to pull her from the water, but she succumbed to her injuries at the scene. Prof Annette McIntosh-Scott from the University of Chester paid tribute to Mrs Collyer, recalling her as a "hugely valued and loved member of staff" who had dedicated 15 years to the Faculty of Health and Social Care. Her colleagues remembered her as a passionate and committed educator, with a special focus on child healthcare, and her students were at the very center of her teaching endeavors.

A native American bird, believed to have originated from the US, is thought to have been swept across the Atlantic by Hurricane Gert while migrating to South America. According to Martin Cade of the Portland Bird Observatory, the sighting is "pretty remarkable." This is reportedly the first time a warbler has been seen in England. The birds are commonly found in the US and annually migrate between North and South America. Cade speculates that the warbler may have become entangled in storms while crossing the Caribbean and was then blown across to Europe with a strong tailwind. Another warbler has been spotted on Mizen Head, the south west tip of Ireland, in recent days. Cade described the bird, approximately the size of a robin, as "feeding well and appearing active." He suggested that the warbler may be feeding up before heading south to Spain and Africa. News of the arrival drew twitchers from as far as the Midlands, South Wales, and Yorkshire, with many traveling to the location on Monday.

Arsenal's 28-year-old Chilean midfielder, who netted the decisive goal in Sunday's FA Cup semi-final against Manchester City, still has a year remaining on his current contract with the Gunners. Despite being a crucial player, he has yet to commit to a new deal. When questioned about the player's potential departure, Arsenal's French manager, Wenger, expressed his confidence that the player will stay with the club. He emphasized that the player is highly valued and unlikely to be sold to another Premier League team. Meanwhile, Wenger is focusing on identifying transfer targets for the upcoming season, which he believes are crucial for the club's future. As he himself is also out of contract at the end of the season, Wenger is working diligently to ensure the team's success, both in the present and future.

Gene Palmer, a second prison worker, has been arrested and detained in connection with the recent prison break at the Clinton Correctional Facility. Joyce Mitchell, a colleague, has already been charged with aiding the escape of the two convicted killers, Richard Matt and David Sweat. The inmates allegedly used power tools to escape from their cells, and a massive manhunt is currently underway to apprehend them. Palmer has been released on bail after appearing in court, facing charges of promoting prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence, and official misconduct. According to his lawyer, Andrew Brockway, Palmer did deliver the meat containing the power tools, but claimed he was unaware of their presence or the inmates' escape plans. Brockway stated that Palmer regrets his actions and plans to plead not guilty. Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie has revealed that Joyce Mitchell was responsible for providing the tools, highlighting the extent of her involvement in the prison break.

The H3 project, implemented in 2014, aims to streamline back office services for four police, fire, and council authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, potentially saving up to £5 million annually. However, the Police Federation has criticized the project, citing a plethora of errors since its inception. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner has promised improvements by May, despite a report highlighting issues with recruitment and staff sickness management, as well as the overburdening of police officers with administrative tasks. Notably, the project has been marred by mistakes, including the incorrect payment of salaries to 1,300 officers in February 2016 and the miscalculation of allowances in March. Furthermore, payment delays to Hampshire County Council's suppliers tripled under the new system in 2015. Hampshire Police Federation chairman John Apter has expressed concerns about the project's impact on officers and the effectiveness of their work.

Two individuals, a 22-year-old from Sleaford and a 25-year-old from Bracknell, were apprehended by law enforcement officials on Thursday. It is alleged that the males were involved in a series of attempts to breach the Microsoft network between January and March of this year. Both suspects were subsequently charged under the UK's Computer Misuse Act, which prohibits unauthorized access to computer systems. According to authorities, the duo was part of a larger group that aimed to infiltrate the software giant's systems, with the intention of stealing customer data. As part of a coordinated operation, detectives from the South East Regional Organised Crime Unit (Serocu) executed raids, which resulted in the confiscation of devices believed to have been utilised in the cyber-intrusion.

Jutanugarn, 20, posted a flawless round, sinking not a single shot and making six birdies, bringing her within striking distance of the tournament record of 19-under par. Mirim Lee from South Korea, who had led after the first and second rounds, fell to second place with a 69. Scotland's Catriona Matthew will begin the final round six strokes behind in fourth position. A win on Sunday would make Jutanugarn the first Thai golfer to claim a major title. Having narrowly missed out on victory at the ANA Inspiration earlier this year due to a triple bogey on her final three holes, Jutanugarn believes she has learned valuable lessons from that experience. During her third round, she demonstrated remarkable composure and consistency, and told BBC Sport that she feels more equipped to handle pressure: "I think I know how to play under pressure. I just need to focus on what I can control."

During a discussion at the IMF meeting in Washington, Christine Lagarde expressed her views, stating that the outcome in the UK is undeniable and successful. Despite the differences between the IMF's forecast of the future deficit and the Office for Budget Responsibility's more optimistic prediction, Lagarde downplayed these discrepancies, attributing them to varying calculation methods rather than substantive differences. This conversation took place alongside George Osborne and Wolfgang Schäuble, the finance ministers of the UK and Germany, respectively. Lagarde noted that in election years, the teams responsible for forecasting future deficits often err on the side of caution, assuming that announced measures may not necessarily come to fruition. She commended the UK authorities for striking a balance between spending cuts and revenue generation, which, in her opinion, is yielding positive results. Lagarde highlighted that when examining the growth rates of various European countries, the UK's comparative performance stands out, underscoring the effectiveness of its economic strategy.

Transport for London (TfL) is planning to launch a public consultation on new regulations for the private hire industry, which could significantly impact Uber's operations. The proposed changes include requiring drivers to pass an English language test, demonstrate map-reading skills, and have access to a fixed landline, as well as the ability to book rides seven days in advance. If implemented, these rules could fundamentally alter the way Uber operates, according to the company, which warned that they would effectively bring an end to the service as it is currently known. Black cab drivers, on the other hand, have long advocated for stricter regulations in the industry. The recent protest outside City Hall is a testament to the growing pressure on lawmakers to address the issue. The Uber app relies on GPS technology to connect customers with nearby drivers and provides an estimated fare. Fares are typically lower than those charged by traditional taxi companies, and drivers use technology for navigation purposes. All transactions are cashless, with payment made through pre-registered bank accounts. According to TfL, the consultation aims to enhance industry standards following the rapid growth of the private hire sector and the increasing use of technology. However, Uber perceives the proposed regulations as a deliberate attempt to target them, and if implemented, they would likely result in higher prices and increased congestion.

On average, "superfans" in the UK spend £581 annually on music festivals, often opting for premium packages or upgraded camping experiences. This demographic, predominantly male, also tends to purchase music in physical formats, such as CDs, or as digital downloads. The findings were based on a survey of 504 UK residents who had attended at least one festival in the past year. According to Eventbrite, the ticketing platform that commissioned the survey, these dedicated fans play a significant role in driving the music festival market, frequently recommending music and events to their friends. They account for 28% of the festival-going audience and are more likely to attend events alone, with 54% stating they would do so. Although they spend an average of £45 more per event compared to casual fans, their loyalty is not assured, as 46% express concerns that festivals are becoming too commercialized. With over 100 music festivals held annually in the UK, ranging from prominent events like Glastonbury and T In The Park to smaller gatherings, the "superfans" are a vital part of the festival-going landscape.

Sterling gained 1.86% against the dollar, reaching $1.3240, and 1.73% against the euro, reaching â‚¬1.1957. The FTSE 100 index touched an 11-month high before retracting and closing with a negligible change of 6,680.69, a mere 2.17-point decline or 0.03%. In contrast, the FTSE 250 index, which is more focused on the UK, rose by 68.75 points, or 0.4%, to 16,775.14. The property sector, which was severely impacted following the Brexit vote, received a boost from Galliford Try's statement that it still expects to meet its full-year profit targets, causing its shares to surge 8.5%. Financial stocks, another casualty of the post-referendum market fluctuations, also experienced a turnaround. Aviva's shares rose 4.26%, while Lloyds Banking Group's shares showed a similar uptrend.

A fishing boat, the MV Karen, suffered substantial damage in April after a British submarine tangled its nets and pulled it 18 miles off the County Down coast. The boat's skipper praised the crew's good fortune in escaping unharmed, but warned that the repairs would cost approximately £10,000. Following an initial denial of comment on submarine activity, the Ministry of Defence (MoD) has now confirmed that a British submarine was involved in the incident. According to the Royal Navy, new information has come to light revealing the UK submarine's responsibility for damaging the MV Karen. In a statement to the House of Commons, Minister for the Armed Forces Penny Mordaunt expressed regret over the incident, attributing it to the submarine's failure to identify the Karen as a fishing vessel with nets deployed, leading to the unfortunate consequences.

Kian Delos Santos, a 17-year-old, was tragically killed by police who claimed he was involved in the drug trade and resisted arrest. However, surveillance footage has raised questions about the incident, showing the teenager being dragged away by plainclothes officers while he was reportedly kneeling, facedown, on the ground. The funeral procession in Manila was attended by hundreds of mourners, who carried placards demanding an end to President Duterte's violent anti-drug campaign. Many citizens, weary of the country's drug-related crime, have rallied behind the movement. The funeral cortege, led by nuns, priests, and hundreds of children chanting "justice for Kian, justice for all," made its way from a church to the cemetery where Kian was laid to rest. Kian's father, Saldy, spoke briefly during the Mass, pleading for his son's innocence and expressing outrage at the police. His emotional plea, "Don't they have a heart?" was met with murmurs of agreement from the mourners, who felt that the police had failed to demonstrate empathy. Saldy also appealed to the police to visit churches, suggesting that perhaps they could find solace and guidance there.

The construction of a new lane, situated adjacent to a section of the existing canal, commenced merely a year ago. This 72-kilometer (44-mile) stretch of waterway enables two-way traffic and accommodates larger vessels. On Saturday, several container ships from around the globe successfully navigated the route as part of a trial run, accompanied by helicopters and naval vessels as part of the security operation. The Sinai Peninsula, which borders the canal, has been plagued by Islamic militants since the Egyptian military's 2013 coup that ousted President Mohammed Morsi, resulting in the deaths of hundreds of people. The original Suez Canal, opened nearly 150 years ago, connects the Mediterranean to the Red Sea. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi claims that the expansion of one of the world's busiest shipping routes will stimulate trade and boost employment nationwide. Currently, the canal handles 7% of global sea-borne commerce, and is one of the most vital shipping lanes globally.

A Leeds Crown Court hearing has revealed that James Carragher, a former head of St William's, a boys' home in Market Weighton, East Riding of Yorkshire, is facing trial for 50 counts of indecent assault against 19 former pupils between the 1970s and 1990s. This is not the first time Carragher has been convicted of sex offences, having previously served seven years in 1993 and 14 years in 2004 for similar crimes. Two other former staff members at the home, which was run by the Catholic De La Salle order, are also on trial for their alleged involvement in the abuse. The home, which catered to boys with behavioral issues, has since been closed. The prosecution, led by Richard Wright QC, claims that Carragher had a long-standing, deeply ingrained sexual attraction to children and young boys, and that he deliberately concealed his true nature behind a façade of respectability.

The 23-year-old defender has signed a three-year contract with Rangers, having made the move from Vitoria Setubal for an undisclosed fee. In an interview with Rangers TV, he expressed his determination to adapt to his new surroundings and succeed in his new environment. "I'm committed to giving my best and supporting my teammates to achieve victory," he said, adding that a club of Rangers' stature should be winning. A former Portuguese Under-21 international, Cardoso made 23 appearances for Vitoria Setubal last season, having previously played for Benfica. He is the second Portuguese centre-back to join Rangers this summer, following the arrival of Bruno Alves from Cagliari. The pair have been joined by midfielder Dalcio, who has been loaned to the club from Benfica.

Morgan Tsvangirai, a longtime critic of Robert Mugabe, and former Vice-President Joice Mujuru have announced plans to collaborate in the upcoming election. However, it remains uncertain which of them will serve as the presidential candidate. Mugabe, now 93, has held power since Zimbabwe's independence in 1980 and has expressed his intention to seek re-election. Tsvangirai noted that this development marks the beginning of efforts to forge a broad alliance to challenge Zanu-PF leading up to the next election. The alliance is a crucial step in uniting a fractured opposition, and if successful, it would mark the first time Mugabe has faced a united opposition on this scale since taking office in 1980.

During a meeting with a group of MEPs on Wednesday, Jean-Claude Juncker reaffirmed his commitment to democratic expressions and respect for Scotland's referendum decision. When asked about the potential for Catalonia and Scotland to join the EU, he emphasized that membership cannot be achieved through a simple letter or declaration. The meeting was sparked by Catalan MEP Josep Maria Terricabras' inquiry into Juncker's stance on the upcoming Scottish independence referendum in September. Juncker maintained a neutral tone, stating that he is in favor of democratic expressions but will not predetermine the outcome. He reiterated his intention to respect the result of the Scottish referendum. Later, Scottish UKIP MEP David Coburn asked about the possibility of an independent Scotland remaining in the EU, to which Juncker responded that the ultimate decision lies with the UK.

A Facebook chat forum created by Harvard students was flooded with offensive content, including jokes about child abuse, sexual assault, pedophilia, and the Holocaust, as well as racial slurs targeting minority groups. The disturbing posts were made by members of a group that originated from a student messaging platform established for incoming Harvard students. The offshoot group, dedicated to sharing mature and provocative content, required new members to submit a meme deemed "edgy" enough to gain entry. Shortly after its formation, Harvard administrators discovered the group and launched an investigation, prompting students to express concerns over the severity of the university's response. Free speech advocates criticized the university's actions, labeling the punishment as "excessive." The Crimson, Harvard's student newspaper, reported on the incident, revealing the scope of the offensive material and the ensuing controversy.

Community leaders from Santa Clara County have initiated a petition to recall Judge Aaron Persky, who has been under fire for his perceived leniency in sentencing Stanford University swimmer Brock Turner in 2016. Turner, who was accused of sexually assaulting an unconscious woman at a fraternity party, received a six-month jail sentence, which sparked widespread outrage. The notice to collect signatures for a recall petition describes Judge Persky's decision as "stunning," citing the severity of the crime and the minimal punishment handed down. Leading the recall effort, along with 50 community leaders, is Stanford law professor Michele Dauber. She emphasized at a recent news conference that "Santa Clara County residents deserve a judge who will protect victims, not rapists" and that "women have had enough of rape culture."

Each year, contestants are challenged to spin the most elaborate and convincing yarn within a five-minute timeframe. George Kemp, a resident of Maryport, Cumbria, emerged victorious despite being hindered by a chest infection. His winning tale revolved around an unexpected encounter with Donald Trump and his wife at an underwater hotel, where he claimed to have stumbled upon a peculiar invention – a small submarine constructed from his father's vintage bubble car. According to George, this underwater adventure took him to the Isle of Man, where he crossed paths with several notable figures in a Scottish submarine fashioned from shortbread tins. He even claimed that Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond sold a batch of these enormous shortbread tin submarines to the United States of America. Last year's champion, Mike Naylor, also known as Monkey Liar, from Wasdale, secured the second spot, followed closely by Helen Jordan. Notably, comedian and TV personality Sue Perkins has previously taken home the top prize.

A recent investigation revealed that a mere 28% of Welsh speakers had used their native language when interacting with their general practitioners, dentists, and opticians. The report's author, Ms Huws, expressed hope that her findings would mark the beginning of an era where patients can access healthcare tailored to their unique needs. The Welsh government welcomed the report, committing to respond within six months. The inquiry, which drew on the experiences of over 1,000 Welsh speakers, found that an overwhelming 90% of respondents believed they should have the right to use Welsh in NHS settings, regardless of their location in Wales. The report's findings also highlighted the difficulties faced by Welsh speakers who struggled to convey their thoughts and emotions to English-speaking doctors, often feeling awkward and uncertain. In response, the report makes 33 recommendations to the Welsh government, urging ministers to provide a clear policy direction, an action plan, and a timeline for implementing changes to support the use of Welsh in primary care settings.

The proposed Welsh Trade Union Bill seeks to repeal specific provisions of the 2016 UK Trade Union Act. This would result in the relaxation of existing restrictions on industrial action in the National Health Service, fire service, schools, and other devolved services in Wales, which are currently subject to UK government regulations. According to the UK government, industrial relations are a matter for Westminster, and they argue that strikes should only be authorized if backed by 40% of a union's members in a ballot. However, members of the Welsh Assembly's Equality, Local Government and Communities Committee believe that the new legislation is essential to maintain Wales' "social-partnership" approach. In March, Welsh Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford emphasized that it would be a "democratic outrage" if the UK government attempted to obstruct the Welsh Trade Union Bill. The Labour Welsh Government asserts that UK ministers should not impose restrictions on union activity in Wales, particularly in devolved services like the NHS and schools. The committee's report did not receive unanimous support, as Conservative AM Janet Finch-Saunders was the sole dissenter.

Eleven-year-old Evha Jannath suffered a fatal accident on Tuesday while on a school trip at Drayton Manor's Splash Canyon, a thrilling water ride. In response to the incident, several theme parks with similar water-based attractions have taken precautions to ensure visitor safety. Drayton Manor has announced that it will remain closed on Friday to facilitate a thorough health and safety investigation. Merlin Entertainments, the company behind Legoland Windsor and Alton Towers, has also taken swift action, immediately shutting down the rides in question on a precautionary basis. According to the spokesperson, the company plans to reopen the rides once the necessary safety checks are completed, likely by Friday. Not all theme parks have followed suit, with some, such as Lightwater Valley in North Yorkshire and West Midland Safari Park, choosing not to suspend operations despite the tragic incident at Drayton Manor.

Rangers secured an unassailable lead with an early own goal from Ally Gilchrist and a powerful strike from James Tavernier. Andy Halliday added a penalty, while Kenny Miller capitalized on a scoring opportunity to ensure Rangers claimed the trophy in their fourth attempt. The team will now face Celtic in next Sunday's Scottish Cup semi-final. Notably, Rangers have a history of struggling in the Challenge Cup, previously falling to Queen of the South, Raith Rovers, and Alloa Athletic. However, they have finally broken their curse and will move on to face Premiership leaders Celtic at Hampden. The national stadium is set to receive a new pitch by then, a much-needed upgrade given the subpar surface that Rangers and Peterhead were forced to play on. The latter, a part-time team, entered the tournament as 22-1 underdogs.

The Royal College of Midwives (RCM) is poised to suspend work for four hours, following a unanimous 9-1 vote in favor of strike action - a historic first in the organization's 134-year history. The Department of Health expressed disappointment over the decision, stating that it will collaborate with trusts to ensure a safe and uninterrupted service for mothers and infants. The department also emphasized its willingness to engage in open discussions to resolve the dispute. The RCM is demanding urgent talks with the health minister to address the issue. According to RCM NI director Bredagh Hughes, midwives are demanding a 1% pay increase, matching the raises given to their counterparts in Wales, Scotland, and England. Hughes emphasized that the dispute is not with the women receiving care, but rather with the Department of Health and employers. She assured that no woman will be put at risk, as full emergency cover will be provided, with midwives on the picket line available to fill any gaps.

According to the latest update, the number of current account customers impacted by the fraud is significantly lower than the initial 20,000 reported. The bank assured customers that their personal data remained secure, and all affected accounts have been fully refunded. Tesco Bank recently revealed that it was the target of a highly sophisticated and systematic cyberattack over the weekend. In response, the bank has taken steps to restore normal operations, with CEO Benny Higgins stating, "We've now refunded all customer accounts affected by fraud and lifted the suspension on online debit transactions, allowing customers to use their accounts as usual." Online payment restrictions were temporarily imposed on Sunday to prevent further fraudulent activity. The CEO expressed regret for the distress and inconvenience caused by the issue, adding, "We're aware of the exact nature of the attack, but cannot disclose further details at this time."

To work in the construction industry, professionals must hold a CSCS card, which certifies their skills and knowledge of health and safety. However, a joint investigation by BBC London and Newsnight uncovered evidence of organized cheating. According to Carl Rhymer, of the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB), one of the test providers, around 6,000 cardholders will need to retake the exam. The CSCS card is widely regarded as the UK's premier scheme for certifying builders, and is required by nine major construction companies, including Crossrail and Heathrow. The investigation found that numerous test centers were offering guaranteed passes for a fee, allowing workers without a sufficient grasp of English to obtain qualifications and gain access to hazardous construction sites. During the investigation, the BBC exposed Wep HSE in Ealing, whose award-winning director, Garet Estensen, was caught reading exam answers from a screen, instructing candidates to follow along. When confronted with the evidence, Mr. Estensen declined to comment. The investigation also uncovered similar malpractices at two other test centers, Future Training 4 and another.

The cyberattack affected computers across the city's transport network, including stations, which displayed a message from the attackers. The message read: "You Hacked, ALL Data Encrypted. Contact For Key (cryptom27@yandex.com) ID:681, Enter." Yandex is a Russian internet company that offers email and social networking services. Fortunately, the trains themselves were not impacted, and city officials have initiated a full investigation. According to a spokesperson, there has been no disruption to the transit service, safety systems, or customers' personal information. The investigation is ongoing, and no further information is available at this time. The Municipal Transportation Agency, or Muni, manages the city's trains, trams, and buses.

The British duo, Wiggins and Cavendish, were defeated by Moreno de Pauw and Kenny de Ketele of Belgium in the final madison event. Wiggins, 36, has announced his intention to retire after the Ghent Six Day event in November, but left the door open to a potential change of heart. When asked about the possibility of returning, he joked, "Money talks," suggesting that the prospect of competing at a high level again could be tempting. Wiggins expressed his love for racing and the possibility of reconsidering his retirement. The event took place at the Lee Valley velodrome, a venue that holds fond memories for Wiggins as it was the site of the London 2012 track events and where he trained as a youth. He declared that it would be an ideal place to conclude his career in Britain, stating, "It has such fantastic memories for me. I will always come back - I'll probably be back next year, but in the stands." The Six Day event kicked off on Tuesday and featured Wiggins and Cavendish in competition.

According to the Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) report, cockpit footage indicates that the plane responded to the pilot's control inputs. The report also stated that pilot Andy Hill was ejected from the aircraft during the later stages of the crash on August 22nd. It remains unclear whether Hill initiated the ejection process. The 51-year-old pilot is currently receiving treatment in hospital for serious but stable injuries. The report suggests that the Hawker Hunter's canopy was released upon initial impact, causing the release of fuel and fuel vapour, which subsequently ignited. As a result, the jet split into four parts, and both Hill and his seat were thrown clear of the cockpit. The investigation is ongoing to determine whether Hill attempted to initiate ejection or if the canopy and pilot's seat were liberated due to impact damage to the cockpit.

Around 200 elite athletes and up to 25,000 amateur runners will take part in the World Half Marathon on Saturday, March 26. The 13.1-mile course will begin outside Cardiff Castle and conclude on King Edward VII Avenue in the city center. According to Dave Bedford, a former 10,000m world record holder, the route is "a great course" that showcases Cardiff's best features. The flat terrain takes participants past iconic landmarks such as the Millennium Stadium, Cardiff City Stadium, Penarth Marina, Cardiff Bay Barrage, Wales Millennium Centre, and Roath Park Lake before finishing in a grandstand setting in the city center. As the first time the event is held in Wales, the 2016 World Half Marathon aims to further elevate Cardiff's reputation as a premier racing destination, particularly with double Olympic gold medalist [name] scheduled to participate.

A stretch of land extending from Bo'ness Harbour to the former Kinneil colliery is set to become a sanctuary for wildlife and vegetation. This marks the creation of the second Local Nature Reserve within the Falkirk Council area. The council intends to leverage the reserve designation to secure funding for the area. The new status signals the conclusion of an era for the site, which spent nearly two centuries being utilized for heavy industry before the closure of its central colliery in 1983. Some areas of the site have already been recognized for their environmental significance, with the mudflats and "island" off the foreshore designated as a Special Protection Area due to their conservation value. Councillor Adrian Mahoney, convener of leisure, tourism, and community, welcomed the new status for the Kinneil foreshore, stating: "This year marks the 30th anniversary of the closure of Kinneil Colliery, the last pit in the area, which has allowed for a transformation of this previously industrialized space into a haven for local flora and fauna."

Conservative councillor Spencer Flower, 72, was found guilty of voting illegally in 2013, despite claiming his involvement with a social housing company was unrelated to the debate over the future of housing in east Dorset. The court ruled that the company could have potentially benefited from the plan being passed, which constituted a breach of the Localism Act 2011. Although found guilty, Flower will be allowed to continue serving in public office. He received a six-month conditional discharge and was ordered to pay £930 in costs. In a statement outside the court, Flower expressed surprise and disappointment at the verdict, stating that the decision was based on a "technicality." He also emphasized that the court acknowledged the absence of any personal gain or intention to benefit from the vote. However, he declined to comment on his political future.

Interestingly, McCartney himself had recorded an earlier version of the track, which he sent to Black while she was performing at the London Palladium. Until recently, the original recording was thought to be either lost or destroyed, but it was later rediscovered by her nephew. Following his growing discontent with the numerous options and vast amount of recorded information presented on call centre menus, Mr Clarke undertook a project to address this issue. He found that some automated menus boast an astonishing 80 options, which can lead to a lengthy process of navigating through menus to reach the desired service. According to Mr Clarke, it can take over four minutes to access the required service if callers listen to each stage in its entirety. For instance, to speak with an adviser at HM Revenue and Customs, only four button presses are necessary; however, it can take up to six minutes to complete each menu level, he noted. HMRC has acknowledged the need for improvement and is working to enhance its service. A spokesperson stated that the organization is exploring ways to improve its interactive voice responses and preparing for the introduction of new speech recognition technology, which will enable callers to communicate with the service by speaking rather than selecting options using their phone's keypad. HMRC plans to implement these upgrades later this year.

As the deadline for Syria's removal of its chemical arsenal was set to expire on Sunday, UN Envoy Sigrid Kaag highlighted the need for urgency in the process. The country's entire chemical weapons stockpile is slated for destruction by June 30, in line with a 2013 Russian-US agreement brokered in response to a sarin rocket attack in Damascus that claimed hundreds of lives. The multinational mission to eliminate Syria's chemical weapons is overseen by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). Although the UN has set June 30 as the ultimate deadline, Syria had initially pledged to complete the removal of its stockpile by April 27, having already missed several previous deadlines. "The majority of the chemical weapons material has been removed, but not yet destroyed, and this counts towards the 30 June deadline," said Ms Kaag, head of the OPCW-UN mission. "Therefore, it is crucial to expedite the destruction of the remaining chemical weapons material at the single site in question."
